Message.Title: Lowest Close Since December 7, 2011
Message.Msg: Today's close was the lowest daily close since 12/7/11 when it closed at $19.20 But today's action isn't good. Took out yesterday's and Monday's highs, then took out yesterdays and Monday's low and closed down on the day. Historically, this has led to a swift $0.80 to $1.00 decline as the weak longs get flushed out. Not getting bearish but rather suggesting that there is a very good likelyhood of a sharp downside correction from here over the next several days. Hence, don't be suprised. And please, don't shoot the messanger here....just trying to look ahead at what could unfold here. The correction of the 30+% move from last September is underway. JMHO

Topic.Title: Buy / Sell Ratio High Today!

Topic.Title: Reason for decline

Message.Msg: The good thing is that Yahoo has the comfort knowing that they can still buyback stock and that they still have their investments in their Asian assets (even if that is already priced into the share price). All of that is backup though. The real stock boost comes with new innovation along the lines of Flickr, Axis, Connected TV, IntoNow. As they gain momentum with new innovations they need to continue to work on dominating their major properties (news, sports, finance, entertainment (OMG), etc) while also improving their core money makers....search and display. That's quite a plate full! But that's exactly why they got a new CEO and governing board!

Message.Title: Bad
Message.Msg: Wednesday, January 9, 7:40 PM Data from comScore shows that Yahoo's (YHOO) November and December U.S. search traffic fell 28% and 24% respectively Y/Y. The report also says traffic to it's mail service was down 16% and 12% for the same period. That's another big hit to a company whose biggest selling point has always been the sheer size of its web traffic.

Topic.Title: Bad

Message.Msg: That's not just bad, it's tragic. MM might be able to right the ship, but unless analysts start seeing some traction, they are going to start bailing out. So far, MM is nothing but hype. She may well be the next Steve Jobs, but the time of assuming she will turn Yahoo around is over. Now it's time to start seeing some strategy, plans, and action.

Topic.Title: My Yahoo mail hacked along with others off topic

Message.Msg: Did yahoo create this problem to extract money from our email accounts its funny, they won't acknowledge the problem [publically] they won't fix the problem you report unless you pay them money and they won't allow us to have a 'topic' on this problem on their message board about yahoo. i found this very complicit. i would not want to be a shareholder of theirs if this is how they treat their membership and i would certainly dump their email account and get one with another provider like g.mail, msn or aol.

Topic.Title: Yahoo will combine assets in a buyout + cash + Asian properties = 25 to 30 in 2013

Message.Msg: The sum of the parts is the value....watch for her to unlock for shareholders.....$$$$$$$$ Do a private market valuation...see you in mid 20s

Topic.Title: Yahoo will combine assets in a buyout + cash + Asian properties = 25 to 30 in 2013

Message.Msg: The sum of the parts may be the value, but it is certainly not the stock price. Stock price is based on earnings and earnings growth. Selling assets is not a business plan (how many times do I need to say that). Unless Yahoo can increase revenue and earnings, than I'll see you in the mid-teens. You people need to quit worrying about selling Alibaba and start worrying about the fact that Yahoo is losing millions of users and advertizing dollars.
